awd_titl_txt: REU Site:   Place-based Conservation Science in Hawaiian Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to University of Hawaii at Hilo, located in Hilo, HI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-2020. The REU program places primary emphasis on tropical ecological research in degraded ecosystems. Interns will participate in professional development, field trips, and outreach, attend the State's annual conservation science conference, and prepare an oral presentation and final paper. This work is expected to spark the research careers for the next generation of environmental problem-solvers through intensive writing training, solution-oriented research topics, and a supportive program structure. The program concentrates on the health and restoration of degraded ecosystems by investigating the spatial spread of degradation as well as ecosystem functioning of resilient communities. The primary focus will be on attracting students with a passion for the environment and nurturing the confidence, skill set and ability to effect positive change and pursue a viable career in this field. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily underrepresented minority students (Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander in particular), first-generation college students, and students with little to no research experience, will work with a diverse team of faculty mentors on projects focused on the ecology of degraded landscapes. Students will learn how research is conducted, and present the results of their work at an internal symposium as well as at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program as well as multiple internal methods. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://hilo.hawaii.edu/uhintern, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Ostertag at ostertag@hawaii.edu), co-PI (Dr. Puniwai-Ganoot at npuniwai@hawaii.edu), or project coordinators (Linnea Heu and Rita Miller at uhintern@hawaii.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
REU:Hanakahi emphasizes research with a place-based approach to understanding the conservation of Hawaiian ecosystems. The UH Hilo 10-week cohort-based summer program is intentionally structured to provide participants with the critical knowledge, quantitative tools, communication skills, cultural sensitivity, and overall acumen needed by researchers of tomorrow. The REU program's placement within the larger and long-established Pacific Internship Programs for Exploring Science (PIPES - http://hilo.hawaii.edu/uhintern/) allows for REU participants to be exposed to broader research topics, management experiences, and environmental education experiences. REU:Hanakahi is designed to attract science students with a passion for the environment as well as demonstrate that scientific training can lead to a viable career in STEM fields relating to resource management and aloha 'aina. 

The program supported 34 students, a majority (62 %) of whom were underrepresented in STEM. The program was run in 2018, 2019, and 2021; it was skipped during 2020 due to COVID, one student was supported with these funds in 2022, and another student was supported by a REPS supplement. The 29 research mentors represented university professors, federal government and state government agencies, social enterprise, and non-profit organizations. 

The summer activities involve a four-day mandatory orientation that introduces interns to program components, expectations, themes of collaboration and shared kuleana, and research methodology. PIPES staff interact with interns on a weekly basis in-person and via Google Classroom to help support students on their academic and personal journeys. Weekly in-person interactions include our Māhuahua (professional development workshops) and huakaʻi (service-learning excursions). The in-person nature of these activities also facilitates a deeper connection between staff and interns, as many of our Māhuahua and huakaʻi involve group interactions. Mentors are also invited to these activities. Students also attend the Hawaii Conservation Conference, which was held in Honolulu for the first two years of the program until COVID interfered; they have some mandatory sessions they attend and also are exposed to networking opportunities. Finally, we provide training for mentors called Kumu Māhuahua, where in three lunchtime sessions we explore student self-efficacy, different learning styles, tips for motivating their interns, and the process of building confidence and encouraging teamwork. 

Students must complete an internship development plan, which functions like a proposal of the planned work and involves input from their mentor. They write bi-weekly internship progress reports read by program staff in which they reflect on their progress and the expectations of the internship and address any sticking points or problems encountered. The final deliverables are an oral presentation and a written report in a scientific writing style that is worked on in sections over the summer. All REU students gave an oral presentation at the end of the summer at our annual symposium, with at least 100 faculty, students, and conservation agency personnel in attendance. The symposium was streamed online via YouTube to reach a broader audience and for partners, mentors, family, and friends who could not attend in person. The one REPS participant, meant for those who missed research experience because of the pandemic, had already graduated and did not participate during the summer time, but did complete the same deliverables. 

Of the interns that filled out the the Student Assessment of Learning Gains (n = 24), 20 of them reported good or great gains in their confidence in their ability to contribute to science and 23 reported good or great gains in their engagement in real-world science research. 

REU interns have used the program as a springboard into conservation jobs and academic pursuits. Most have graduated with a Bachelor's degree. In addition, some are in MS programs (2 alumni are in the Tropical Conservation and Environmental Science program at UH Hilo) and some are currently applying for MS and PhD programs. In total, 12 conference presentations and 10 peer-reviewed publications have been associated with this award. The UH Hilo REU program is one of many supportive programs and experiences which contributes to the success of an individual student and ultimately the entire field of conservation science.
